content: Go to Help > Troubleshooting Information > Application Basics > Profiles > about:profiles. Launch the others one at a time and restart TB. If they all give the setup screen, try creating a new profile (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles).

content:
> not necessary to show every time the program is opened.

It is part of the design to display the account creation dialog, in order to assist (most) users in this situation who will also tend to me new, to not have to guess what to do for initial configuration.

When you did the import process, did it not create an account, and then cause the new account creation to not display?
creator: wsmwk

content: Thanks Wayne. Yes, I set up my primary personal account, completed the import, then followed the same process for another 9 accounts connected with business and creative activities. Very easy and straightforward. I certainly appreciate that displaying the setup dialog is essential for a new user to follow, but expected that once the process had been completed, opening the program would display a menu header above a blank message frame, perhaps showing the TB logo, rather than repeating the configuration dialog every time the app is opened (regardless of whether the checkbox had been ticked or left unticked). Anyway, it's no big deal, and it doesn't detract from the the fact that in every other way I'm finding TB suits my simple "send and receive email" needs much better than the bloated "bells and whistles" alternatives.
creator: nmrn2012

content:
> option to open with a blank page is not working despite leaving the checkbox unchecked.

Sounds like you are describing the Start Page checkbox in Settings. (greater detail in your description will be helpful). Start page is what is shown in the message display pane.

Lacking the reference of a screen shot of your system, I'm guessing what you are seeing is what we call "Account Central". It is a hub of information and actions when an account is selected. It is displayed in the entire right side of the window where message list and message display pane are seen when a folder has been selected.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova describes the normal layout with folder selected.

content: Perhaps if you walk us through what you are doing someone can guess as to what he issue is, but if it affects webmail as well as mail clients it is probably third party software like an antivirus, or it could be your images. These tend to appear in emails as a blank placeholder, often in a frame.

content:
re :Trying to enable calandar on thunderbird.

Thunderbird has a built in Calendar which it auto calls 'Home'. It is already created. There is an icon shortcut to the 'Calendar' via the left vertical 'Spaces Toolbar' or use 'Alt 3'

You can also access it via the 'Menu Bar' Toolbar

  • 'Events and Tasks'
  • Select 'Calendar' and it opens in a new tab.

To enable the 'Menu Bar' toolbar - I would do this anyway as it has a load of easy to find menu items.

  • Menu app (3 lines) > 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Menu Bar'

Settings > Calendar This is where all the default Calendar settings are located.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you are trying to create a new calendar (in addition to the default) eg: you want to synchronise with a gmail/google calendar: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/using-lightning-google-calendar

You can also easily do this from the 'Calendar' view Open 'Calendar' Bottom of left pane is a 'New Calendar' link - follow instructions.

content:
If you use any program that uses 'localhost' such as 'Apache' 'Xampp' then you need to switch it off whilst setting up 'Oauth' token. Some people use programs to manage websites and they use 'localhost'.

If you use a VPN then gmail will not like it because it looks like you are hacker, gmail expects the IP of your computer, so you need to switch off VPN or create a split tunnelling and set it up to allow Thunderbird to use it.

If you have previously set up a gmail account and it's now asking for password etc - first check you have got no VPN operating and thet your Firewall has Thunderbird as an allowed program.

Have you set up Thunderbird to allow cookies ?

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • WEb Content
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies: 'Always'
  • Click on 'Exceptions' :
  • set up: https://accounts.google.com' as 'Allow'
  • Click on 'Save Changes'


If you previously set it up but need to reset passwords, oauth token etc. In addition to all above - clear/remove all stored password for the account.

  • Settings > Privacy & SEcurity'
  • Passwords section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Remove all passwords that you see for that gmail account. Whether they are 'mailbox://account..' or 'Imap://account...' or 'Smtp://account...' or oauth://account...'

So there's nothing stored.

then restart Thunderbird

content:
I'm not sure what the question is or what problem you are experiencing with Thunderbird.

re :Let me know if you’d like a workflow to export Thunderbird emails into a legally robust format similar to `.pst`.

It does sound like you are trying to offer a service to Thunderbird users that has nothing to do with Thunderbird issue or query on how to do something. Meaning you do not have an issue with something in Thunderbird.

I do not intend to sound rude towards you, but I would be 'naive' to respond to you in order to save my personal data in an alternative format.

Please note, saving in an alternative format does not mean the emails have not been tampered prior to that action. So the reasoning of saving an in an alternative format just in case you think it might be used in a legal situation is now a moot point. That does not mean saing in another format would be useful in certain situations.

AS a heads up .pst files can be exported to other formats, altered and then resaved as pst. But I suspect you are already aware of that fact. So just because it's a pst file and in Outlook does not mean it's not had any alterations. But I agree it's not so easy to alter as an mbox file.

Outlook emails can be exported as eml files. There are plenty of pst to mbox and vis versa converter programs. Any email regardless of whether viewed in Outlook or Thunderbird or any third party email client can be copied and pasted into various programs and manually altered prior to printing. It can also forwarded to any email address as an attachment and therefore imported into any email client. When I say email - I do mean you can also 'view the source' not just read the visible email.

It's easier to manipulate an mbox file - this is true - assuming you know what you are doing. Also assuming you have computer User Rights to access it, many do not have those rights when working for companies. It also means it's easier to recover emails in many circumstances.

User Access rights to mail storage folders is already something that can be set up by organisations which offers some additional protection. So would in effect protect mbox files. This does not make it completely secure as someone always needs accessibility for obvious reasons, but it limits access and increases the integrity of emails.

Many legal situations prefer emails to be stored in a pdf format which can be done in Thunderbird if desired. Emails whether downloaded in Outlook, Thunderbird or any other third party email client will be acceptable in legal cases but the credibility of e-mail evidence will be scrutinized in all cases and that is expected.

re :b. Lack of Server-Side Enforcement Thunderbird relies on whatever SMTP/IMAP servers it connects to. Unless the server enforces policies (like DKIM signing, DMARC, or header filtering), client settings are only soft limits.

Anyone can own a domain and not just companies or a business and set up DKIM. Therefore a valid DKIM signature alone is not necessarilly an indicator for a trustworthy e-mail.

I think you will find most servers now perform DKIM checks. You can easily see the DKIM information in the 'View Source' of emails whether using Outlook or Thunderbird.

In addition there is a Thunderbird addon DKIM Verifier just in case people want to see that information in the Message Header area, but servers perform those checks and Thunderbird is not a server.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thank you for your detailed reply, Toad-Hall!

I have asked Chat GPT to explain to me your reply (I need to do that because I am not a technical person), and I think I have understood where the misunderstanding is.

I am not asking for Thunderbird emails to be converted into a legally acceptable format. What I am asking for is for Thunderbird to be made such that the emails that it downloads from, say, a Gmail server are a little more legally acceptable.

My cyber security lawyer had told me that Outlook client emails are valid proof in the courts of law, but Thunderbird emails are not. The reason that he told me was that Outlook client emails do not allow the header of the email to be edited after it has been sent, while there are lesser restrictions on Thunderbird emails. It is possible that he explained to me in simple language without covering all the technical aspects but simplified it for me by saying that the difference lies in whether the header can be edited or not.

By now, I am beginning to understand that it is not so simple as just whether the header can be edited or not, but has many other nuances to it. While I am not a techie, and am unlikely to understand these nuances, I can explain my question better below.

If there is anything that can be done to improve the legal validity of emails downloaded from the Gmail server into the Thunderbird client (possibly by making changes in the way that Thunderbird downloads and stores emails), then would it be helpful to have that done? If, over a period of time, it improves to the level where emails downloaded by Thunderbird from the Gmail server are acceptable to a court of law, at least in India, which accepts Outlook client emails downloaded from the Gmail server, then it would add considerably to the utility of Thunderbird.

This is what I was trying to say and I request you to let me know, in simple words if possible, whether such improvements can be made to the Thunderbird software. Even if it is in highly technical language, I can always ask Chat GPT to explain it to me.

My whole request was not a problem that I faced in Thunderbird, but a suggestion to make Thunderbird even better. I assume that I have been able to explain my question better and I look forward to your reply on whether Thunderbird would consider it worthwhile to move in that direction, if it is not already doing so.

Thanks and Regards, Tapan (Tapan Singhal)
creator: tapan.datapower

content:
I understand you seek a means to have Thunderbird be more "trustworthy" in this use case. But as David alludes to, there are vectors for creating deception. An email from Outlook for example could have been altered on the server or by some email client other than Outlook.

This is why an email in its paper or electronic form must (as I understand it) be proved in court by some legally acceptable means of verification that the content is a true representation of the original. For example, a human testify that yes, this is what I sent on such and such a date, from place X, to person Y.

Thunderbird is not the only client capable of altering messages.

content:
Several times a day, when I try to fetch messages, I have to confirm security exceptions.

Please post a screenshot of the error. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/how-do-i-create-screenshot-my-problem

Also, what is your anti-virus/security software?

The confirmations never seem to stick.

Typically that happens when your anti-virus software is intercepting your secure connection to the server by generating a certificate on the fly. When that happens, Thunderbird is showing the exception prompt, because it cannot confirm the validity of the cert being presented.

This is some BS.

No it's not. If this is what happens, Thunderbird is protecting you from security software essentially performing a man-in-the-middle attack. This is the same what malware listening in and replacing legitimate server certificates with their own would do. Sadly most people getting the exception prompt don't have a clue what it means and are just complaining about it.
creator: christ1

content: Here are several screenshots of the notification and security exception screens I receive when trying to retrieve mail and send mail from two domains I own and have e-mail accounts on. This is in Thunderbird for Windows. I have Bitdefender Total Security on my desktop PC, which runs Windows 10. I'm experiencing the exact same problem in Thunderbird for Linux, on which I do not have any antivirus software installed. I experienced the problem once in Thunderbird for Android on my phone, but it hasn't recurred. I do have Bitdefender Security on my phone. So if the problem is my antivirus software, why is this problem occurring on my Windows 10 desktop PC and my Linux laptop, but not on my phone? And why did the issue crop up for me at the same time as it did for Earthlink users?
creator: Catbus

content:
I'm experiencing the exact same problem in Thunderbird for Linux, on which I do not have any antivirus software installed.

Not exactly. There are two different error codes. In the first screenshot - assuming this is on the Windows computer running Bitdefender A/V software: "The certificate for ... does not come from a trusted source."

On the Windows computer, click the 'Get Certificate' button, then 'View'. This should open a new Certificate Viewer window with the certificate details. Please post a screenshot of that window with the 'Issuer' information visible.

In the other screenshot - assuming this is on your Linux computer: "The certificate is not trusted because it hasn't been verified as issued by a trusted authority using a secure signature."

A problem with A/V software can be ruled out here. So the problem could be a missing intermediate or root certificate. As a result Thunderbird cannot verify the entire certificate chain, hence the exception prompt. That wouldn't explain why exception prompts are show frequently though. So it may still be some thing else. But more information is needed.

So even though you do get an exception prompt in both cases, the cause is different for each. I have no idea about Thunderbird for Android. Presumably certificates are being handled on the OS level, while desktop Thunderbird is using it's own certificate store.

content:
UFL mail is built on MS servers, and such accounts automatically copy sent messages to the Sent folder. So, it's necessary to uncheck 'Place a copy in' in the Copies & Folders section of Account Settings (your picture). Also, the Sent folder should be subscribed (right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe...). See if that eliminates the error on sending.

https://it.clas.ufl.edu/kb/imap-thunderbird-configuration/

content: My suggestion is to unsubscribe from both Important and AllMail. That reducees your disk space noticably and also reduces your cpu use and time to send and receive. gmail keeps everything in one folder, but an email client must simulate that by creating duplicate accounts. To summarize, do NOT attempt to clean the Important folder as that deletes from everywhere. Instead, unsubscribe so that you and Thunderbird don't need to worry about it.

content:
Hello there We have read that message.

To stop Thunderbird of check spelling go to tools>options>composition>spelling uncheck the box next to Check spelling as you type On the end click on okay.

If you want another language you can change that in the program . Or you can change the language in the system.

Greetings googlethunderbird.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content: I am NOT the IMAP guru here, but I do know that IMAP accounts may act differently, some updating online whenever there is a new message. My IMAP accounts update on their own as mail arrives. This is not a Thunderbird bug. I think, at one time, the IDLE command could be disabled, but I am not aware of any current ability to do that.
creator: davidsk

content: click settings>general to remove the startup page. But please periodically donate. Thunderbird relies on user support. Thank you for your donation.
creator: davidsk

content:
david said
click settings>general to remove the startup page. But please periodically donate. Thunderbird relies on user support. Thank you for your donation.

I disabled the Thunderbird Start Page in General settings, but I'm still getting served the donation page.

I donated two months ago, but still keep getting donation requests. I didn't donate to get rid off the donation requests, but it would be nice if donors wouldn't be spammed with donation requests anymore.

It's becoming very annoying.

I used the same email-address to donate with as I use for my account Mozilla account. It would be nice if the donation request would seize after donating.
creator: Marty1111

content: I think what you're seeing (as I get that message too) is a web page popup. That happens to all of us periodically to request donations. Fortunately, it doesn't happen frequently. My guess on the periodic request is that a one-time donation doesn't support the program. Also, to save your info locally would go against the Mozilla philosophy of protecting/respecting your privacy.
creator: davidsk

content: Hola Eso depende del formato que se ha exportado es compatible con la herramienta de importación de Thunderbird: https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/versions/ Saludos
creator: pcp04

content: Is this a google based account? Turn on filter logging?
creator: wsmwk

content: Wayne, thanks for the suggestion and yes it is a google based account, but this did not resolve it. According to the Thunderbird Tools/Message Filters widget, there are no filters enabled for this account. I turned on logging, sent a message (which was starred when it showed up), and checked the log again: nothing in the log. Any other ideas?
creator: dan_suthers

content:
Can you post a screen shot?

No gmail filters?
creator: wsmwk

content:
Wayne, thanks so much. I was only looking for filters in Thunderbird. Turns out I had NEVER logged into the gmail interface for this account: I only accessed it via Thunderbird. (This is an account passed between chairs every 3 years.) When I did log in to gmail.hawaii.edu web interface, it gave me a first login info screen as if no one had logged in before. Eventually I found the filters screen that your screen dump shows and indeed a previous user had set up the star filter for emails sent from and to the same account. (Perhaps she was using messages to herself as a to-do list? Also found that she was forwarding to a now defunct gmail account, which explains error messages I was getting.)

I really appreciate your help but have a suggestion: don't assume too much and explain your questions. It took me some time to realize what you meant by "gmail filters' and where to find them.

Dan
creator: dan_suthers
